Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Increasing Participation of U.S. Students to the 9th International Conference on Micro-Manufacturing (ICOMM 2014); Singapore, 25-28 March 2014

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this award is to provide partial support to selected students studying in US institutions to participate in the 9th International Conference on Micro-Manufacturing to be held in Singapore, 25-28 March 2014. This is a premiere global conference on micro-manufacturing which draws large attendance of researchers and engineers each year from America, Europe, and Asia. Over one hundred papers covering a wide range of topics pertinent to micro-manufacturing and micro-engineering are expected to be presented at the conference. The attending students will participate in the conference by presenting technical papers they have authored. The funding opportunity will be broadly announced giving students ample notice and time to apply. Applications will be reviewed by the conference scientific committee. A total of sixteen students will be partially supported from this award which will help offset expenses for travel, conference registration, and lodging.

In addition to nurturing a global micro-manufacturing vision, participating students will learn about the latest research progress and challenges in micro-manufacturing by attending technical presentations by leading international experts in the field. The students will also have opportunities to exchange ideas with leading researchers and engineers from worldwide industrial and governmental facilities, as well as the opportunity to visit companies and laboratories involved with micro-manufacturing in Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this award was to provide partial support to selected students studying in U.S. institutions to participate in the 9th International Conference on Micro-Manufacturing held in Singapore, 25-28 March 2014. This is a premiere global conference on micro-manufacturing which draws large attendance of researchers and engineers each year from America, Europe and Asia. A total of 110 papers covering a wide range of topics pertinent to micro-manufacturing and micro-engineering were presented at the ICOMM2014 conference.

This grant supported 8 students who attended ICOMM2014 conference. This grant also supported 4 students for ICOMM2015 conference which was held in Milan Italy in March 2015 and other 4 students who participated in the ICOMM2016 conference held in Irvine CA in April 2016.  Thus, a total of 16 students were supported from this grant. In all these international conferences, each student participant had to present a paper or a poster for 30 minutes and participated in the discussion sessions where questions emanating from the presentations were asked.

In addition to nurturing a global micro-manufacturing vision, participating students learned about the latest research progress and challenges in micro-manufacturing by attending technical presentations by leading international experts in the field. The students had the opportunities to exchange ideas with leading researchers and engineers from worldwide industrial and governmental facilities, as well as the opportunity to visit companies and laboratories involved with micro-manufacturing. All three conferences had three keynote presentations in additional to regular conference sessions. The keynote papers featured important areas of micro manufacturing. These keynote papers were critically important to the students, as the speakers discussed emerging areas of research pertaining to micro-manufacturing and discussed key research directions and visions on micro-manufacturing. At the ICOMM2014, the student had the opportunity to visit Singapore Institute of Manufacturing Technology (SIMTech) center, whereas, at the ICOMM2015, the students had the opportunity to visit manufacturing research laboratories at Milan Polytechnic. ICOMM2016 featured tours on micro manufacturing research laboratories at the University of California, Irvine.

This grant has provided the student participants greater opportunities for networking, fostered future collaborations and exchange of ideas with other researchers in the discipline which should enhance likelihood of future innovation. This experience is very valuable to young engineers in developing their careers in the manufacturing field. The grant has also exposed our next generation of engineers and researchers with a global perspective
